bookmarks.description:
How to use Leetcode effectively - Byte by Byte

 

+ Sort your Leetcode challenges by - Frequency

+ Start with Easy challenge Problems

+ Write your solutions on a piece of paper first - Copy it "letter" for "letter" to leetcode

+ Debug your solution on paper first

+ Talk out loud when you're solving

+ Add Review points
5 Common Mistakes when using Leetcode - (Really useful advice) - Java Brains

Pitfall #1 - The details aren't always thre

 

Unlike Leetcode Problem description, The Interviewer will give 1 sentence, maximum 2 sentence about the interview question

 

+ Start with just the Problem statement / first sentence, nothing else. (Don't read through the whole problem)

+ Start asking out loud, - "Clarifying questions"

+ You're not practicing for solving Leetcode

+ Because you saw the problem on leetcode, if you're to say - "Hey I have seen the problem, I have solved it on leetcode", it will only work for your dis-advantage

 

You're expected to ask clarifying questions, you're expected to uncover hidden information in the problem.

Pitfall #2 - Working code isn't everything

 

"Is your code readable, is your code something the interviewer can understand, are the variables named correctly, code syntaxes, even pseudo code syntaxes"

 

+ When you're writing code using Leetcode, it verifies for accuracy

+ You can structure your code however you want, it will check out

+ When you're interviewing / white-boarding - working code, is just one of the several factors the interviewer is going to evaluate

+ Is my code readable, can the interviewer understand my code, how are variables named ?
+ You need to write sensible variable names!!!

Pitfall #3 - Your code isn't evaluated, YOU ARE being evaluated

 

+ In Leetcode, you're evaluated for your final output

+ In an interview, you're evaluated for your PROCESS you took to approach the solution

+ Speak out loud "Think aloud".

+ When you're writing code on leetcode, imagine someone sitting next to you and speak out loud

 

"Verbalize your process... you're evaluated for the PROCESS not the final outcome"

Pitfall # 4 - Focusing on things that don't matter

 

+ Comparing performance and memory usage and trying to improve solution, B.S !!

+ It's super fun to tweak your program, in an interview that's not what people care about

+ Nobody compares your solution in an interview

+ They might ask if a different Data-structure can be used, 

+ They expect you to reason about your solution

+ They might ask about Time complexity

 

"Don't care about speed, performance, Worry about time complexity, maybe datastructure"

Pitfall # 5 - Not practicing in the right setting

 

+ Leetcode allows you to write on an editor, that's not the scenario during coding interviews

+ Typically coding interviews are white board interviews, or on a notepad (like google)

+ Write code on a piece of paper! (truer words have not been spoken !!)
